title: Projects
section: - H5Nx transmission dynamics and assessment of the intervention strategies
text:
- H5Nx transmission dynamics and assessment of the intervention strategies
he H5Nx avian influenza virus poses a significant threat to both poultry industries and public health due to its high fatality rate and potential for pandemic spread. While no evidence of human-to-human transmission of H5Nx, the zoonotic spillover events remain a major concern due to the virus’s high fatality rate in humans (~60% mortality historically). Therefore, it is essential to understand interspecies transmission dynamics and quantifying the effectiveness of possible interventions strategies such as culling, vaccination, biosecurity measures which are critical for mitigating risks. Mathematical models provide a powerful tool to simulate transmission pathways, forecast outbreak trajectories, and compare the impact of control strategies across species. Hence, I develop a coupled mathematical framework to analyze H5Nx transmission dynamics in both human, domestic and wild populations.



.


Geospatial Risk Mapping of H5N1 Spillover to Humans Across US States 

The rise of H5N1 avian influenza as a potential zoonotic threat has underscored the need for better preparedness and response strategies to mitigate the risks posed to human populations. This virus has a tendency to cause severe illness in humans following possible spillover from infected birds. So, in this context, understanding the geospatial distribution of risk factors is essential for informing public health measures and enhancing surveillance systems.
Hence, this project aims to develop a geospatial risk map of H5N1 spillover to humans across various U.S. states, identifying areas of heightened vulnerability and prioritizing regions for enhanced surveillance and preparedness. By integrating multiple data sources including historical H5N1 outbreaks in animals, ecological factors, human population density, poultry industry locations, climate variables etc, this work will assess the risk of H5N1 transmission from animals to humans and its potential to spread within human populations.

title: Oluwatosin Babasola,PhD
text:
I am a Postdoctoral Researcher at the University of Georgia, specializing in leveraging mathematical tools to address complex problems in industrial and environmental settings. My research interests span Numerical Analysis, Mathematical Biology, Financial Mathematics, Dynamical Systems, and Climate Modeling.
I completed my PhD as a researcher at the EPSRC Centre for Doctoral Training in Statistical Applied Mathematics at the University of Bath. My doctoral work focused on analyzing time-delayed systems to investigate the effects of climate change on agriculture. Specifically, I developed mathematical models to explore how time lags between flowering and harvesting stages affect cocoa crops, to predict their behavior as global temperatures rise.
Before embarking on my PhD, I earned multiple master’s degrees in various areas of mathematical sciences. As an African Union Commission scholar at the Pan African University, I developed novel numerical approaches for pricing exotic financial options, with a particular focus on barrier options. I am also an alumnus of the African Institute for Mathematical Sciences (AIMS), a leading institution for mathematically talented African students, as part of the Next Einstein Initiative. Additionally, I had the honor of participating in the Heidelberg Laureate Forum, an exclusive gathering of the world’s most promising young researchers and renowned laureates.
My academic journey began in Nigeria, where I graduated with First Class Honors in my bachelor’s program and earned a Distinction in my MSc degree in Mathematics, both from the University of Ilorin.

title: Training
text:
We’re excited to announce that Ultralytics, a top company in creating AI models, has noticed our research. Ultralytics is known for its cutting-edge AI work, especially its Ultralytics YOLO (You Only Look Once) technology. This technology is at the forefront of image classification and object detection, setting benchmarks for speed, accuracy, and efficiency in vision AI. Their shout-out to our work on Twitter shows that what we’re doing is important and impactful. Being recognized by such an influential company in AI proves that our research is valuable and makes a real difference in the tech and science worlds.
Check out the tweet by Ultralytics here.
